twitter.content:
And in Germany, authorities want to silence debate about deportations of criminal aliens.

Regulators said that a post calling to deport immigrants accused of more than 100 crimes constituted illegal “incitement to hatred.”

parentTweet.content:
In France, regulators want to silence debate about Europe’s mass migration policies.

Police sought the removal of this post satirically noting that permissive French immigration and citizenship policies may have caused a violent attack by a Syrian asylum seeker.

posts.author: liberty4alll
posts.title: When you realize almost all of the Constitutional amendments have helped Democrats and hurt Republicans.

posts.raw_content:
I have noticed that a lot of H1Bs work remotely. H1B sponsorship is when a local "talent" cannot be found. If the company does not need the person to live locally, then logic dictates that it does not need the H1B. 

There are some H1Bs who *never* visit the HQ. In the days of Zoom, why cannot these people work from their home country?

If the H1B is not needed in the office, shouldn't the person be hired in their own country? The employer does not know even now if this person is moonlighting for many jobs. Psst -- they are!

They claim to be working from a certain address and very often relocate to another cheaper location without informing USCIS. This causes three problems.

1. They have robbed a local fellow of his job. 
2. They are drawing a salary that is not commensurate with the local levels. So one can claim on their application to be living in the same area code as the employer and be happy with a lower salary. This constitutes a violation of the LCA issued by USCIS. 
3. If the employer is in on this, all H1B applications of the employer should be audited. There is never one cockroach. The employer is then actively screwing the American over and should not be allowed access to the H1B pool. Further, the employer should not be allowed to feed off the government funds.

If the H1B is not needed on a regular basis, may be these people should be asked to live in Mexico or some other American country in the same time zone. 

I also wonder about the security implications. This guy can be anywhere accessing sensitive data that his homeland may also be accessing. The employer allegiance to the country is suspect once he is part of the fraud. Who knows if the company is really adhering to the DoD regulations?

Have you seen any remote working H1Bs? What are your personal experiences?
